title: 106_hr5461
content: The "Shark Finning Prohibition Act" aims to eliminate shark-finning by addressing the issue nationally and internationally. It prohibits the removal of shark fins and discarding shark carcasses at sea. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to include a prohibition on removing shark fins and discarding carcasses at sea. It also prohibits having shark fins without the corresponding carcass on a fishing vessel or landing fins without the carcass. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act now prohibits the landing of shark fins without the corresponding carcass on a fishing vessel. If the weight of shark fins exceeds 5 percent of the weight of shark carcasses landed, it is considered a violation. The Secretary of Commerce must issue regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment to implement a provision of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. Additionally, there are provisions for international negotiations. The Secretary of Commerce, in collaboration with the Secretary of State, is required to initiate discussions for bilateral or multilateral agreements with other nations to prohibit shark-finning. They must also engage in discussions with foreign governments involved in shark-finning to gather information and establish treaties to protect shark species. Additionally, they are tasked with seeking international agreements through the United Nations to ban shark-finning and other harmful fishing practices. The United States aims to collaborate with international bodies to protect shark species by amending existing treaties, urging governments to collect biological and trade data on sharks, and encouraging the submission of National Plans of Action for conservation. The United States aims to collaborate internationally to protect shark species by submitting respective National Plans of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks to the FAO Committee on Fisheries. SEC. 6. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with the Secretary of State, must provide Congress with an annual report identifying nations involved in shark-finning, detailing international shark fin trade, efforts to implement the Act, a plan for shark conservation measures, and recommendations to ensure compliance with national and international obligations regarding shark populations. The annual report must detail international shark fin trade, efforts to implement the Act, and recommendations for compliance with national and international obligations regarding shark populations, including those under CITES. SEC. 7. RESEARCH. The Secretary of Commerce will establish a research program for Pacific and Atlantic sharks, focusing on data collection for stock assessments, identifying fishing gear to minimize shark bycatch, researching fishing methods for shark survival after release, and developing methods to release sharks from gear safely. Research on maximizing utilization and funding for sharks not taken in violation of fishing management plans, studying foreign fleets' harvest of sharks and shark fins, and analyzing the international trade in shark products. The National Marine Fisheries Service will collaborate with the commercial longlining industry to conduct research activities related to the Act, including shark cooperative research programs. Shark-finning is defined as removing a shark's fin and returning the rest to the sea. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2001-2005 to implement the Act.
